terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Belgian countryside near Turnhout. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Belgian event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Turnhout Gravel is a regional event in Belgium—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Belgian countryside is nice and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Belgian rolling gravel race. Worth it for European riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Europe—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Belgian terrain: Heathland Gravel.

logistics.food: Turnhout has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Belgian rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Still missing basic traveler info like parking and lodging, though the race starts and finishes in Turnhout city center 'next to the cosy harbour.' With 2,534 riders from 27 countries selling out two months early, the demand clearly outpaces the published logistics support for international participants.

length.explanation: Elite winners averaged 40 km/h over 144km (the longer distance option), with Mads Würtz Schmidt finishing in 3:35:24. The 72km medio race saw Gurvan Ollivier win in 1:59:08. Two distance options let you pick your suffering level, both long enough to separate fitness but not epic endurance tests. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Course update for 2026 puts it: "The course will get an update near Merksplas on the north side of the course with new tracks and better traffic management, but the major update comes in the long 15km stretch along the canal where ri..."

technicality.explanation: Course features 'champagne gravel' - fine, crunchy American-style gravel with 'long straight wide open gravel boulevards' through meadows and forests. Winner Geerike Schreurs attacked on 'technical singletrack' in the final 10km where positioning becomes critical, but most terrain is fast and straightforward. Less technical than The Mid South. As Geerike Schreurs puts it: "I had several flat tires and had to chase back multiple times. At one point, I rode over 35 kilometers on a flat tyre."

elevation.explanation: Only 100m of elevation gain per lap on the flat Kempen terrain. The course runs through 'wide open gravel boulevards amidst meadows and nature reserves and long stretches through forests and along the channel.' Your legs will feel 144km of distance, not climbing. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Even elite riders struggled with equipment failures - winner Geerike Schreurs 'had several flat tires and had to chase back multiple times. At one point, I rode over 35 kilometers on a flat tyre.' Sandy sections and potential mud led organizers to reroute away from the canal twice. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Course update for 2026 puts it: "The course will get an update near Merksplas on the north side of the course with new tracks and better traffic management, but the major update comes in the long 15km stretch along the canal where ri..."

altitude.explanation: The flat Kempen region keeps this race at sea level through meadows and nature reserves. If you're looking for altitude training effects, you picked the wrong country - Belgium's highest point barely qualifies as a hill. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Long stretches through forests and along the channel offer pleasant Belgian countryside, but nothing remote or exotic. The course updates for 2026 include 'new tracks and better traffic management' near Merksplas, suggesting civilized gravel with good infrastructure rather than wilderness exploration.

prestige.explanation: Drawing WorldTour pros like Sophie Wright, who left six years of WorldTour racing because 'I want to try something pretty different, and also go back to my off-road roots.' Former pros Laurens Ten Dam and Thomas De Gendt also raced the 2025 edition, lending credibility to this young event. As Qualification importance puts it: "Riders finishing in the top 25% of their UCI age/gender categories automatically qualified for the upcoming Gravel World Championships."

race_quality.explanation: The women's elite race 'stayed closed for a long time with a final with 14 women elite' before Schreurs attacked with 10km to go. Course updates for 2026 show organizers are actively improving routing and traffic management, suggesting they're learning from early editions.

experience.explanation: Harry Tanfield expects gravel racing to be wild compared to WorldTour road racing: 'you have to line up like one hour before the race...and then everyone's fighting for position.' The mix of wide gravel boulevards and technical singletrack delivers both power and positioning challenges.

community.explanation: Sold out two months early with 2,534 riders from 27 countries, making it 'the biggest event so far in the UCI Gravel World Series.' Top 25% finishers automatically qualify for Gravel World Championships, creating serious racing atmosphere alongside recreational participation.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, elite fields included Danish riders Mads Würtz Schmidt and Magnus Bak Klaris who broke away in lap two, eventually settling it in a sprint. The race attracts both WorldTour refugees and gravel specialists, though Belgium's gravel scene is still developing compared to its cyclocross heritage. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: No published entry fees, but selling out two months early with 2,534 international participants suggests reasonable pricing for UCI World Series qualification opportunities. Automatic Worlds qualification for top finishers adds significant value beyond the race experience itself.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €50-80. Belgium isn't budget-friendly, and with no published lodging recommendations, international travelers are planning blind. The March timing could mean decent weather or Belgian mud season - Schreurs rode 35km on a flat tire, suggesting conditions can turn expensive quickly. Higher total cost than Badlands.
